info.title: Migrating from KVM for IBM z Systems to KVM integrated with SUSE Linux Enterprise Server
info.productname: SUSE Linux Enterprise Server for IBM z Systems and LinuxOne

affiliation.jobtitle: Technology Strategist - Alliances and Integrated Systems

abstract.para: On March 7, 2017, IBM announced the end of support for KVM for IBM z Systems. To learn more, read the official IBM Withdrawal Announcement at . Preceding the IBM announcement on March 1, 2017, SUSE announced full support for KVM in SUSE Linux Enterprise Server for z Systems and LinuxONE 12 SP2 and newer versions. You can find more details in the article at .

Customers that are using or testing KVM for IBM z Systems may have been using the IBM Redbook Getting Started with KVM for IBM z Systems at . This SUSE Best Practices document will cover the most important details about how to migrate a virtual machine from KVM for IBM z Systems to KVM in SUSE Linux Enterprise Server.

sect1.title: Installing SUSE Linux Enterprise for z Systems and LinuxONE as KVM Host
sect1.para: Like KVM for IBM z Systems, KVM in SUSE Linux Enterprise Server is supported when installed into an PR/SM LPAR. The section Installation on IBM z Systems of the SUSE Linux Enterprise Server Deployment Guide at provides information regarding supported hardware and memory requirements for installing into an LPAR. The section Overiew of an LPAR Installation at reviews the preparation and initial steps in starting the SUSE Linux Enterprise Server Installation System.

A suggested partitioning layout includes separating the storage of the KVM disk images from the operating system. Using the BTRFS filesystem for the operating system enables rollback capabilities when patching the system. The default location for the KVM disk images is /var/lib/libvirt/images/. It is recommended to use Logical Volume Manager with the XFS filesystem for KVM disk images.
For the Software Selection in the installer, use the list below for the minimum and suggested additional patterns to be installed.

listitem.para: GNOME Desktop Environment & X Window System (needed for managing virtual machines using a GUI)

sect1.para: Make sure to register and patch the KVM host either during the initial installation or after the installation is complete.

sect1.title: Managing KVM Instances
sect1.para: It is recommended to use utilities that manage virtual machines using the libvirt API. The section Managing Virtual Machines with libvirt at provides information about using both command line and GUI based tools. It is strongly recommended to use the previous link because it contains detailed information about VM installation and management as well as storage and network management for VMs. The sections below provide additional information about accessing a particular tool.

sect2.title: Using the Command Line to Create and Manage Instances
sect2.para: virsh and virt-install are the command line utilities to manage virtual machines. These utilities are installed as part of the KVM Virtualization Host and tools pattern. The section Virtualization Console Tools at provides an introdution to these utilites.
Use ssh to log into the KVM host to use virsh and virt-install.

sect2.title: Managing Virtual Machines Using a GUI
sect2.para: Virtual Machine Manager (virt-manager) is the GUI tool used to manage virtual machines. This utility is installed as part of the KVM Virtualization Host and tools pattern. The section Virtualization GUI Tools at provides an introduction.

To access the virt-manager GUI, use X11 forwarding via ssh or vncviewer. X11 forwarding is a good option if the connection (local or metropolitan area network) speed between the client and the KVM host is fast. Use vncviewer if you find that X11 redirection is too slow. Perform the following actions to enable access to virt-manager.

listitem.para: Both X11 forwarding via ssh and vncviewer
Install the Suggested additional Patterns listed above using YAST or zypper
From a client terminal, ssh -X <KVM hostname>
For vncviewer access to the KVM host
Start YaST and go into Network Services | Remote Administration (VNC)
Select "Allow Remote Administration Without Session Management" and click OK
From a client terminal, vncviewer <KVM hostname::1>
Log in to the KVM host in the window opened by the previous command
Within the X11 forwarding via ssh client terminal and XTerm window in vncviewer window

sect1.title: Moving an Existing IBM KVM Virtual Machine to KVM in SUSE Linux Enterprise Server
sect1.para: This is an example of how to move an KVM for IBM z Systems virtual machine to KVM integrated with SUSE Linux Enterprise Server. A VM was created on KVM for IBM z Systems following the section 3.7 of the IBM Redbook Getting Started with KVM for IBM z Systems at . This procedure assumes that the KVM for IBM z Systems VM has a virtual disk file and is attached to a virtual network defined using libvirt. Below you find the xml definition of the VM and virtual network based on the example in the IBM Redbook.

sect1.para: The VM and network definition for a customer deployment may be considerably different but the basic procedure to move the VM to KVM in SUSE Linux Enterprise Server will be that same, as outlined below.

step.para: Connect via ssh to the IBM KVM host
Find a VM configured on the IBM KVM host that you would like to move to a SLES KVM host
virsh list --all
'virsh dumpxml <vmname> > ~/<vmname>.xml' where <vmname> is a VM to move
less ~/<vmname>.xml and make note of the following information

listitem.para: Location of the VM disk file which is <source file= in the above VM definition
The name of the network bridge which is <source bridge= in the above VM definition

step.para: Determine the virtual network associated to the VM
virsh net-list --all
virsh net-dumpxml <network name> > ~/net-<network name>.xml
grep -H <network bridge name from the information gathered before> ~/net-*.xml
Make note of the filename from the grep output above
Copy the VM disk file, the VM xml file and the network xml file to the SLES KVM host
rsync -S --progress <VM disk file> <VM xml file> <network xml> <SLES KVM Host>:/var/lib/libvirt/images
ssh to the SLES KVM host
Remove bridge if already exists on KVM host
virsh net-list --all
virsh net-undefine <network name> - when the network name is the same as a network name on the IBM KVM host
Add bridge from IBM KVM
virsh net-define <network-name>
virsh net-start <network-name>
virsh net-autostart <network-name>
Edit VM xml file by changing
to
Define VM in SUSE Linux Enterprise Server KVM
virsh define <VM xml file>
Start and verify the newly migrated VM is running
virsh start >VM name>
virsh list
Connect via ssh into the VM to verify that networking is working
